abstract.p: Photo of Indianapolis Colts quarterback Peyton Manning

block.p: The National Football League has rarely enjoyed such a surplus of good young passers, which bodes well for the future at the position. Here is a look at the strengths and weeknesses of some of them:
Charlie Batch (6-2, 220) Detroit Hits deep throws, but is injury prone.
The National Football League has rarely enjoyed such a surplus of good young passers, which bodes well for the future at the position. Here is a look at the strengths and weeknesses of some of them:
Charlie Batch (6-2, 220) Detroit Hits deep throws, but is injury prone.
Brian Griese (6-3, 215) Denver Good touch on passes, but is arrogant.
Shaun King (6-0, 225) Tampa Bay Quick learner, but not a great athlete.
Ryan Leaf (6-5, 235) San Diego Unlimited potential, but is a knucklehead.
Peyton Manning (6-5, 230) Indianapolis Excellent leader, but has an average arm.
Donovan McNabb (6-2, 226) Philadelphia Extremely poised, but scrambles too much.
Steve McNair (6-2, 225) Tennessee Strong arm, but misses short routes.
Cade McNown (6-1, 208) Chicago Makes big plays, but is not a pocket passer.
Akili Smith (6-3, 220) Cincinnati Reads defenses well, but has a slow delivery.
Kurt Warner (6-2, 220) St. Louis Accurate, but telegraphs his throws.
